ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Great for developing your writing skills as well as your ability to carry out research. A great introduction to some really interesting ecological theory that really highlights black and indigenous voices as well as the importance of decolonization. Will help you improve your critical reading ability as some of the readings are pretty complex.
My writing skills improved greatly after a few months of taking this course. Also, my understanding of indigeneity and its importance in today's society grew.
After this course, I developed better general writing skills. I was able to learn about unique perspectives on ecology and environmentalism.
I learned a lot about the interaction between indigenous peoples and their environment and place as a concept.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Professor Tazudeen is super caring and understanding with his students. He is great at guiding the discussions, and the readings for the course are all very interesting and manageable length-wise. Readings are varied from futuristic short stories to theory which helps keep students engaged. Clear feedback on assignments.

Weaknesses: Can't particularly think of any.

Strengths: Professor Tazudeen was amazing and gave clear feedback which helped to greatly improve my writing.
Weaknesses: none.

I really enjoyed the reading for this course.  All the texts were interesting, and the discussions around them were very engaging.  I think one thing that could have been improved was guidance for the discussions -- sometimes the texts were long, so I would have appreciated more clarity about the important parts of them to discuss.

The professor, discussions, and readings were the strengths of this course. Professor Tazudeen and the readings he provided us with gave me a fascinating new approach to thinking about environmentalism, and how it may vary across peoples. This made the discussions very interesting as well. One potential weakness is that the course often focuses so much on the ideas of the readings and the discussions that sometimes there wasn't as much emphasis on improving writing skills. H
Strengths: high engagement, interesting material, good professor

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The usage of occasional breakout rooms was well carried out as it allowed us to engage with ours peers one-on-one but was not overdone.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I would. This course is a super helpful introduction to college writing (professor Tazudeen gives great feedback!) and if you have any interest in environmental topics then you will find this class to be a super engaging opportunity to knock out the writing credit. You'll come out of this class with some new perspectives and it's a valuable course for anyone regardless of major.
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student.  The reading and discussions were very engaging, and Professor Tazudeen gives detailed feedback on how to improve your writing.

I would absolutely recommend this course. Professor Tazudeen always took the time to work with my ideas, and how I could improve my writing as well as my ideas. Moreover,  I found the general content of the course fascinating.

Absolutely. Professor Tazudeen is a great professor and mentor and overall the class was a great experience. If you would like to learn more about ecology, more specifically black and indigenous ecology, I would highly recommend this course. The material was engaging and fulfilling.
